Comment: Actually, it's not only a right, but a duty, for associations to enforce their covenants, and they can be sued for their failure to do so.  Many people move into a covenant-controlled community precisely because they want protection against outrageous behavior of others.  What owners can legally do with their property is established by the covenants of each community, which constitute a contract that is binding on all owners and runs with the land.  Each owner agreed to be bound by those covenants, and the rules that board may adopt from time to time.  The owners elect the board that governs the community, so it is a representative form of government, just like our nation.  What's un-American about that?  And what's in-American about people entering into voluntary contracts?

Comment: It's slack in the system. Our short run aggregate supply curve is flat lining, and aggregate demand is just idling along. There are no pressures from input prices, and no inflationary expectations to get workers clambering for cost of living allowances.

We should just kick back and enjoy the ride for a while. I don't need higher interest rates, we don't need any more inflation than what we're seeing. Most of what we are seeing are ripples from the volatile edges of the CPI shopping basket. That, and the odd tsunami of uncertainty from our erstwhile ally and major trading partner to the south.

For those who think Mr Poloz is anything but competent and intelligent, you need to take an introductory course in macro-economics to find out what his actual job entails. It sounds like you'd be surprised to find it's complex, very challenging, and goes far beyond making periodic pronouncements about keeping the overnight rate where it's at.

Comment: Not exactly.

There are four reasons for the State to exact a penalty: justice, defense against the criminal, deterrence, rehabilitation, in that order of importance.

St. John Paul II first states "the primary purpose of the punishment which society inflicts is 'to redress the disorder caused by the offence'", and then discusses the second reason:

"If bloodless means are sufficient to defend human lives against an aggressor and to protect public order and the safety of persons, public authority must limit itself to such means."

So, if only the death penalty will be adequate to achieve justice, we need look no further.

As to defense against the criminal, there are nations such as Mexico where the criminals are so powerful, and the civil authority so weak, that - as  has been demonstrated repeatedly - imprisonment may be ineffective in defending against the criminal, who run their activities from their cells.

Comment: Accelerated weekly payments of $500 will save you significantly amounts of interest over paying $2,167 per month.  Even accelerated bi-weekly payments of $1,000 will yield substantial benefits.  But the equivalent amount paid on a monthly basis is certainly not virtually the same thin.

In addition to the benefit of 52 payments a year accelerated weekly also means you are drawing down your mortgage every week rather than every month.  Over a 25 amortization period that amounts to about $22K in interest savings on a $150K mortgage.  The reason - interest is computed daily regardless of your payment frequency.  

So yes if you could pay hourly it would be even better.

Comment: Canada in the post-world war 2 era has never been and will never be fertile ground for the sort of harsh libertarianism being proposed by the likely leadership race winner, Maxime Bernier. 

It's a delusional political philosophy that draws its inspiration from a fanciful historical view of the late 1800s and early 1900s, where it is alleged that hard-working and resourceful men (yes, all men) were free from the shackles of big government to pursue their destiny while the unwashed masses wallowed in poverty brought on by their own laziness. 

In reality, the wealthy were largely born wealthy and the poor were born poor, with few opportunities for the latter to improve their station. Greater government involvement in prudently regulating economy and enhancing social well-being in the latter half of the 20th century were critical to establishing the civilized and relatively fair country we live in today. Calls for returning to the dog-eat-dog days of the 1920s will not succeed.

Comment: When I was  7 years old my family lived in Houston and attended an Episcopalian church.    In the front of the chapel was a stain glass of Jesus with arms lowered and outstretched, like a father waiting for a hug.   Being that young and the Episcopalian church being formal, I didn't 'get' the liturgical stuff, or sermons.   I would grab a pencil from the pew and one of the paper programs and start to doodle.   

I remember trying to draw that stain glass during the service and it seems that Jesus would move in ways that you had to look hard to see.  I think he spoke to me but I don't remember any words?   It felt wonderful and personal. 

So, I suppose my morals come from my perception of how I see the life of Jesus.    The emotion was that of the love of child for a parent. 

That small subtle voice has stayed with me.   The problem is that the Spirit wants me to sit quietly and frankly I'm not real good at it.

Comment: "The way you know your new production tax needs reform is because the industry says it's working."

No truer words were ever spoken in the hall of the Alaska Legislature.

A lot of people defend the current tax structure by trying to make a big deal out of the fact that under SB21 Alaska receives more in taxes at current prices than it would have under ACES. But this is not an either / or kind of situation. In other words the options are in no way, shape or form limited to either retaining SB21 or returning to ACES. We'd be having the same reform discussion if we were getting pillaged by the oil companies under ACES as we are under SB21. 

Besides, the pro-SB21 crowd told us that if we passed it, tax revenues would rain down on the state and there'd be jobs jobs jobs. They didn't say, "unless oil prices are $54 per barrel", they flat out told us everybody would "win". But the only winner under SB21 are the oil companies. 

I have 3 words for SB21: Repeal and Replace

Comment: It is yet another wake up call. I live in California, 40 or so miles from the beach, but we all know the storm drains go to the ocean. After a big rain, the harbors get filled with floating plastic bags and styrofoam cups, which eventually sink and drift away.  But all this crap from 7 billion people, and especially those of us at the coasts, isn't just going to biodegrade away.  We just banned plastic bags here in California for grocery purchases. I voted against the State Proposition because I thought it was stupid, but now have changed my mind. We use way less bags; no surprise there.  It is a hassle to bring a bag to the store, but we get by, and sometimes I use no bag at all.  There are ways our civilization can change to solve or at least reduce these problems.

Comment: Those wind turbines in the photo attached to this article are a complete failure.  Wind in the more populated portions of the state cannot produce enough power to even meet the current needs, much less the future.

Sure, Copper Valley and Kodiak have found better ways than burning diesel to produce electricity for their very small populations, but it simply won't work for the more populated areas. I guarantee if they had access to reasonably priced natural gas they would have never developed those projects.

Comment: After having lived in Australia (state of Victoria) for a little bit I'm FIRMLY convinced that there is ZERO benefit to the government-controlled monopoly of liquor sales we have here.

There were all kinds of different alcohol retailers in Australia.  Some focused purely on low price for those that wanted that.  Others focused on excellent selection and great service (definitely superior to the LCBO) for those that wanted that.  Others still were specialty stores offering phenomenal selection of a given product (wine, scotch, beer, etc.).  They really put the power of choice back in the hands of consumers were it belongs, not some government employee telling us how they think we need to shop.

If Ontario truly needs more revenue from alcohol sales they can raise the taxes, but lying to us and telling us that we need to be forced to shop at the LCBO so that they can tax us by means of LCBO profits is just insulting.

Comment: I agree (and here it comes), BUT how can a statistician guarantee the reliability of survey data? The question is, of course, rhetorical: no one can guarantee any such thing. All one can do is try to reduce the margins for error when compiling data. One way of facilitating this is the employment of properly trained surveyors.

Mathematical methodologies for statistical analysis are usually (but not always) reliable: this very much depends on the skill, and honesty (we keep coming back to this word), of  the statistician.

You know, of course, that survey results can easily (and often) be skewed in whatever way a statistician chooses.

Oh! If only statisticians and their respondents were saints: there'd be perfect results every time. (Well, probably.)

Comment: Small quibble.

Stupid laws need to be -repealed-. A large part of the problem with our government is the habit of ignoring the system as designed because it is "too hard" (i.e. requires politicians to put their careers on the line by taking stands one way or another) and instead claiming Constitutional requirements "don't work." Comment: The Vietnam War was fought primarily by citizen soldiers rather than professionals. The fact that the military reached into every town and city in the United States to draft soldiers meant that many families were personally impacted by the conflict. As a result there was a great deal of public scrutiny when the escalating war dragged on year after year and it became apparent that tens of thousands of these soldiers would not be coming home. This is not the situation today where the military is composed of patriotic volunteers many of whom have made it their career. They and their families represent a only very small percentage of our population. This makes it much easier for politicians to send our troops into harms way without a great deal of public discussion.

Comment: Protect the ocean from what?  Hawaii longline fishers?  If so, I would suggest that a critical mass of people have a very poor understanding of how marine resource management, science, and politics actually work.  The expansion is a feel good exercize that's part of a larger and disturbing trend where preservationism is masquerading as conservation and doing the latter a disservice.  A fishery is people and fish.  If we manage just for the fish it will come around to bite us in end.  If we're thinking about our kids and grandkids we should be promoting sustainable use of the resource, not making it off-limits to us and pretending that "reverberations of our self-hinderance" will somehow inspire the massive industrial fishing nations operating in the region to follow suit.

Comment: After Haiti’s eartquake Jan. 12, 2010, U.S. military mobilized like it was going to war. Before the next day, an Army unit was airborne, on its way to seize control of the main airport in Port-au-Prince. Within two days, 8,000 American troops were en route. Within two weeks, 33 U.S. military ships and 22,000 troops had arrived. More than 300 military helicopters buzzed overhead, delivering millions of pounds of food and water.
-   -   -   -   -  -   -   -   -   -   -   -   -   -  
By contrast, eight days after Hurricane Maria ripped across neighboring Puerto Rico, just 4,400 service members were participating in federal operations to assist the devastated island, an Army general told reporters Thursday. In addition, about 1,000 Coast Guard members were aiding the efforts. Comment: "I have never head anyone complain about the Holy Ghost 'proceeding' from the Father and the Son.'  I guess you never heard of the "Filioque Contovesy" [proceeding versus sending] either.
The original completed Nicene Creed [381 A.D], declared that the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father---period.  Western bishops at the Third Council of Toledo in 589 AD added "and the son" to the original version of the creed.  Therefore, the Catholic Profession of Faith states today, "proceeds from the Father and the Son."  But scripture is clear that Jesus says unequivocally, "I will send him [the Holy Spirit] to you."  The Greek Christians agreed with this, but they argued that 'sending' and 'proceeding' are not the same thing.  To them, the word "proceed" was equivalent to the word 'begot,' as in the verse in the creed which refers to the Son as begotten of the Father.  Greek Christians argued that ONLY the Father could beget, and thus BOTH the Son and the Spirit had to proceed from the Father.

Comment: "The Alberta justice system is now a commodity"

The same applies to the enforcement and collection of taxes in Alberta and other parts of Canada. (TO, Vancouver, Victoria, northeast BC)

Unlike the US where pay rates are related to demand and cost of living, pay rates are the same at CRA, all across Canada. This,  of course, results in the places, where there is much wealth (and therefore tax evasion) having very inexperienced staff who are likely to join the "other side", as soon as they can, for a large increase in pay. Meanwhile, economic backwaters (like Sidney NS) have  highly experienced staff, who are often among the best paid in town. The "the poor and desperate" get away with little, in such places. 

Detecting tax evasion is often the first step in detecting other major fraud. Getting it into court - something that is sadly lacking in Alberta - is a major step in outing it.

This couple heard Apollos speak boldly about Jesus in the Jewish synagogue---but not correctly[Acts 18:24-26].  Luke writes, "they took him aside and explained the way of God to him more accurately" [Acts 18:26].

Comment: Yes, it's a popular thought, this.  Liberal welfare scroungers at home eating cheetos, while those earnest, hard-working conservatives go to work every day.  So just because I'm curious this way, I went and looked at the data from the survey we conducted at the end of March, which just so happened to include a question that read "Are you employed full-time, part-time or are you not currently employed in the workforce?".  Crosstabbing employment status by ideology, we don't see anything like what AHHA suggests.  In the total population, 55.2% are full-time, 13.9% are part-time, for a total employed number of 69.1%.  Conservatives were 57.6% + 9.3% = 66.9%, the moderates were 53.8% + 16.2% = 70.0% and the progressives were 54.3% + 16.0% = 70.3%.  So while conservatives have a marginally higher full-time percent, they also show the lowest total employment.  The reality is though that there is no significance in the relationship.  Nothing to be seen here... so move along.

Comment: What people who have medical care need to be aware of is that the medical facilities only bill your insurance as a courtesy to the patient. As a customer of their services it is no different than being a customer of any service, one is responsible for the total bill. There are few business's and none I can think of that is as expensive as medical care where a customer thinks that they are not on the hook for the entire bill. It is up to us to know the bill, what it is for, how our insurance pays and call the medical insurance provider if we have questions. I have many times went to my medical service providers because they had no response from the bill they sent to my insurance and I asked them to re-bill it and followed it with a phone call to my insurance and told them to put my bill on top of their work pile.

Comment: I agree in general that govt sits on way too much land that amounts to dead capital, but the problem is how to realize value from it, or at least break even on it, rather than generate new long-term liabilities from it. A stretch of unused land can either sit on the books generating no return, or it can be serviced for a new township, none of whose residents can be expected to pay rates or utilities bills for perhaps decades. 

It may be though that these liabilities exist whether or not the govt does anything - that's where it starts getting interesting. Govt should perhaps bite the bullet and stop fighting a rear-guard action against the inevitable.

But our current situation is that the state has progressed through serious studies and engineering exercises to develop a potential project, the gas line to tidewater with LNG sales to interested parties. The question is whether or not to proceed and spend piles and piles of money to move forward. There is definitely a market for LNG depending on the delivered price. Now our consultants tell us the delivered price for our LNG is not competitive. If we believe them we should scrap the AKLNG project, if we don't believe them why did we hire them in the first place? If AKLNG dies, then we could go back to look at other alternatives and see which merit further cost development. But we have a question before us to be decided, AKLNG or not. Comment: Since atheists don't believe there is some supernatural entity dictating right and wrong, we have to employ reason to come to the fairest perspective we can. 

In the case of abortion, we weigh all the facts and find we must come to the conclusion that, on balance, there are some instances in which a woman's right to her own body outweighs the right of a possible person to be born. It's not an easy decision to come to but it is a rational one. Basically it comes down to the idea that a possible person is not as important as an existing person. Part of the reasoning behind this is that many possible people are miscarried by natural causes anyway. If we're to consider every possible person as being as important and cherished as every actual person we would have to live in a state of constant mourning at the cruel carnage being wrought (by God, presumably). 

Atheism isn't so much a belief as it is a refusal to conduct oneself according to superstition. We feel obliged to use our brains.

Comment: The TDSB has a history of doing stupid things.

About 20 years ago it removed all the play equipment from school yards because it did not meet CSA (Canadian Standards Association) standards. 

It did so because of a perceived risk of harm to children despite no reports of injuries from equipment that had been in place for years. It did not have the money at the time to replace the equipment which I recall  eventually cost a $million (probably $5 million today).

This was a complete waste of money and play equipment. The situation arose because the CSA changed its standards, which they occasionally do. However, such changes were minor and intended typically only apply to new installations, not retroactively.

Is it not wonderful how fools can spend other peoples money so easily and without any accountability?

Comment: In general, despite some name-calling, this has been a remarkably good conversation.  Thank you for that.  For the sake of discussion I would like to throw in some additional points (sorry if I missed these elsewhere):
1. When talking about cutting services in order to balance the budget, maybe some of that should focus on efficiency as well.  If we are going to try to draw new commercial investors, there is a pretty high level of life-style and infrastructure that we will need to maintain in order to be attractive.  The other end of the slope is that we will all be living a subsistence life-style;
2. I am not sure about the cost we pay for the resources to provide our own energy, but at the gas pump we certainly don't see the benefits of our own resources.  Any role renewables can play seems beneficial for those who's energy costs are already high.
One more thing, but out of "characters".

Comment: The ACLU will easily win.  First Amendment case law is perfectly clear that government cannot be in the position of favoring one religious group or doctrine over another. It's not clear to me, for example, why the fantasies of Scientology aren't a religion while the fantasies of Prevo are.  But taking that approach is an obvious loser for KPB, since it could be challenged by an infinite variety of requests to invocate and it would have to show that every one of them isn't a religion to keep its evangelical skirts untainted.

So Pease is right; the Borough would be far better off getting out of the religion business altogether.  Then all they'd have to worry about is pictures of pyramids in the Homer post office.

Comment: You speak of the Homer Spit in the summer tourist season. Then there is the Homer Spit when is a quiet time to enjoy. I love the beaches in the winter. Just took  photos of some awesome storm waves. Birding is so amazing that the local bird club makes it a daily stop to posts the latest. My grandkids adore the Spit, where sea otters come so close you see what they are eating. And orca and humpback whales can swim by while they are busy building "beach" art. . They love to watch the boats on the ocean. big and small. On a nice day I can launch my kayak out for a quick ride. The way I view it some people like to skim the top of life and others will seek beyond that for the little joys and mysteries that life holds, me, I am not a "skimmer". Like my house in Hawaii I know how to stay away from the tourists.

Comment: As somebody who has owned two mid sized businesses, I disagree with Mrs Reid that this is not a problem for the business. It is a huge issue if the person going on leave is the only one in the department - it is extremely difficult to hire a temporary replacement, especially since the term of the leave is at the whim of the employee - they can extend up to the maximum but can also elect to return sooner. 
The issue is that the situation also involves another person (that is hired as a replacement) and there is also an obligation to treat that person fairly and with respect. There are two employees impacted. 
Currently, the employee does not have to determine in advance how long they will be on leave and it makes it impossible to provide the temporary with a fixed term contract. 
I have been fortunate in the past that any of our employees on the program have been very respectful of the situation of the temporary replacement, but I expect that this is not always the case.

We reject the false choice of housing verses farming poised by this mega project.  Lets embrace both as our future, and deal with the knotty issue of building out the infill in Oak Harbor directly while affirming our farming future

"The people are the only censors of their governors: and even their errors will tend to keep these to the true principles of their institution. Thomas Jefferson

Comment: The NYT is a family owned, old line paper whose influence and distribution has atrophied for 20 years.  WaPo was also family owned and struggling until acquired by Jeff Bezos.  Under Bezos the WaPo has improved coverage and quality of reporting.  Both exhibit an "ideology" which mirrors the opinions of their owners.

Other similar examples are the Boston Globe which was acquired by the NYT for billions and sold soon after for a a pittance to sports mogul John Henry and WSJ acquired by Rupert Murdoch's news empire.

The common thread seems to be ownership by new money with deep pockets and an agenda other than objective reporting. 

Realistically speaking what we are seeing is a reprise of journalism as it existed in the 19th century, an enterprise controlled by wealthy publishers who used it as a vehicle to promote their financial and political interests.

In closing I would agree with HL Mencken:

Comment: Actually, White House officials said this figure came from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Researchers from the Climate Interactive project, which collaborates with MIT, quickly refuted Trump's point.

In fact, the MIT research to which the president referred showed that the Paris Agreement could lower the expected temperature increase by 0.6 to 1.1 C.

The Trump administration essentially pulled one piece of data out of the study and removed all context before inserting it into a factually inaccurate and entirely different claim, said John Reilly, co-director of the Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change at MIT and author of the study. He said his study showed Paris was an important agreement that could shave off an entire degree of warming, but that climate skeptics have tried to make a similar false claim in the past. He said that if anything, the study shows an argument for remaining in Paris.

(Scientific American)

Comment: High income earners pay the lions share of all taxes so it is inevitable that anything that reduces taxes will disproportionately benefit higher income earners.

Put another way, if someone is only paying $20/year in total income taxes, the most you can possibly cut their taxes by is $20, or a 100% decrease.  If someone else is paying $10,000/year in taxes and you cut their taxes by $200 they benefited 10 times as much as the first person even though they only saw a 2% decrease in their taxes.

The notion that we can't have any programs that help reduce the tax burden just because those programs might benefit high income earners more is completely misguided and ignorant.

Comment: Title IX is actually taken incredibly seriously at Toolik. Comment: Good and important topic.

A solution is needed - on how to balance the budget when increasing salaries and benefits so that unfair burden is not placed on the taxpayer.

I've read elsewhere that in Hawaii, for cost-of-living adjustments, and with the addition of benefits, here's how average annual wages + benefits currently stack up:  
  
Private Sector Worker - $55,432; 
State Worker - $68,216; 
County Worker - $86,712.

Government Sector Benefits have grown 5x faster than in Private Sector.

Unfunded liabilities for local government benefits are now $23Billion, highest in state's history.    

So a solution that is fair and of value to all Hawaii residents can not ignore this debt nor ignore the discrepancy between Private Sector and Public sector wages and benefits.

The herd has not recovered to this day. It took 25 years of conservative management to get to 14,000 caribou and Knowles ruined it all. 

Buffer zone proponents refuse to acknowledge that all but one of the wolf packs in Denali are on the eastern park border for a reason. Their prey is on State land east of the park. That happens to be where game is actually managed. The only other pack is on the western park border. You guessed it. Adjacent to State managed lands. Ask yourself why the vast interior part of the Park with a huge no hunt, no manage policy has virtually no wildlife. Go figure!

Comment: Aloha Taipan.  There are, broadly, 2 types of climate change.  First, so called Natural Forcings caused by things like changes in the orbit of the earth around the sun, changes in ocean currents etc.  Typically these changes occur very slowly over millennia or even millions of years. Then there is the climate change caused by humans.  The main cause of this is the emission of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, methane and CFCs, largely as a result of industrial activity, including industrial-style farming and petroleum-fueled transportation - think cars.   These emissions are already causing rapid warming of the oceans and the atmosphere.  The change is happening so rapidly that the planet does not have time to adapt.  If we do not stop, we will see massive disruption, crop failures, droughts, flooding of all the major cities, wars.  Many analysts believe the very survival of humanity is threatened. Here's a report by the top scientists on the planet: goo.gl/6ZBxJX

Comment: 2/2 continuation
An anecdote: In South Africa - the Anglican Bishops met with their first black Bishop to discuss what position they would take on the new marriage laws being imposed by the Nationalist government. They were all agreed that apartheid was morally wrong and would stand shoulder to shoulder with people of all and mixed races etc etc. They then broke up for lunch and went to the restaurant next door - all except 2 of them (the black bishop who was not allowed into a whites only restaurant, and one other who accompanied him). They went without lunch. None of the others were aware of their privilege or behaviour ... until afterwards. It was this bishop who told the story - without rancour, with good humour and with forgiveness - what a witness to Christ's grace. 
I repeat this story, not to point fingers at the Anglicans but to illustrate how easy it is to be 'righteous' in our decisions and yet unaware of our own collusion in racism (or any other privileged '-ism'.

Comment: There is an option that would be a better long term solution. Move the Spanish immersion program (SIP) from its location at Ainsworth to a currently unused facility like east Sylvan. This will open up room for 300 students at Ainsworth.

The overall PPS SIP is a great concept and espouses the goals of diversity, accessibility, and inclusion.

However, the SIP at Ainsworth is the dirty little secret of the Westside. It does not meet any of the above goals. There is no diversity, access is difficult, and it is run like an exclusive private school, funded by taxpayer money. Schools overcrowded? No problem, SIP is capped at 26 students per class. Lack of budget for teachers? Not an issue, SIP has assistant teachers for every class!  

How is this even compatible with the PPS equity initiative?

Moving the Ainsworth SIP will help meet its true goals, but there is strong resistance to this because it would inconvenience some privileged families that live in the mansions close to the school.

Comment: Continued....
CONTEXT:
In Mk 10:5-9, Jesus spoke to the Jewish context of very early Christianity, where divorce was possible only for the husband. There were exceptions, but these were far too few to influence the moral climate. Jesus' radical stance could be seen as defending the position of wives, who were quite vulnerable and could be dismissed for little or no reason at all. The broader intention, however, was
to strengthen the marriage institution among the disciples and align social realities with God's design in creating man and woman. As such, Jesus' prophetic message was an integral part of his proclamation of the kingdom of God and the need to repent and believe the gospel (1:14-15).  
Mark helps us as a people to focus and m a i n t a i n the ideals of married life while dealing with the contingencies associated with the difficulties involved in realizing these in the modern world. Mark's purpose is never to tell us what we must do but to form us as a people

Comment: There's no evidence that Fr. Judge wanted to be married. He became a Friar and, as far as we know, lived his vows as well as other Friars do. The cause for his canonization, if it were to go forward, would be that he lived a life of heroic virtue, in spite of struggling with many of the same issues we all struggle with.
It wasn't until the 12th century that canonizations were reserved to the Holy See. Prior to that time, it was the general practice for the local Ordinary to decree that a person's name be included in the Eucharistic liturgy. If that were still the practice, many Catholic New Yorkers who remember 9-11 would favor their bishop doing just that for Fr. Judge. You can't ride the subways and believe humans achieve perfection in this life.

Comment: Wrong.  Revenues from motor vehicle registration fees and gas taxes pay for a lot more than just "the damage they cause to roads".  They pay for BUILDING those roads in the first place.  They pay for damage by weather, and freeze/thaw cycles.  Sometimes they even get siphoned off to bike paths that motor vehicles aren't even allowed to use.  

Fact is that ONLY motor vehicle owners/drivers pay those extra usage taxes/fees, IN ADDITION to the sales taxes and property taxes and income taxes that everyone pays (not in place of).  Only one group is stuck paying for their actual usage.  Even though the road surfaces that bikes also get to use cost a lot of money to build.

Comment: Ports are locally owned. Local voters, residents, citizens, all have the right to participate in management decision of "their" port. If they do not want certain kinds of traffic, they have every right to refuse. There are probably other ports on the West Coast who might love the business. LNG poses interesting questions. Our state just refused to invest in LNG for electrical generation, why, because LNG is seen as an intermediate step in the transition from liquid fossil fuel to green-power generation (solar, wind, waves, biomass, hydro, etc) and if LNG gets entrenched, it could forestall the transition to green-power. Basically, we, residents and voters of Hawaii have said "No" to LNG here. I guess that makes a wacko out of you and me?

Comment: I would like to see a study that compares the brains of football, soccer, and rugby players.
Studies have shown that excessively heading a soccer ball can contribute to CTE.
Since rugby players don't use helmets and pads, they tend to keep their heads out of it when they make tackles. (They are taught to go in low and keep their heads behind the ball carrier.)
Because of this, they might be less inclined to develop CTE, even though there are a lot more tackles in a game of rugby than in American football.

Comment: and The French Wars of Religion, or Huguenot Wars of the 16th century, are names for a period of civil infighting, military operations and religious war primarily fought between Roman Catholics and Huguenots (Reformed Protestantism, a.k.a. Calvinist Protestants) in the Kingdom of France

and The Strasbourg Bishops' War (German: Bischöflichen Krieg, French: Guerre des Evêques) (1592–1604) was a conflict between Protestants and Catholics for control of the Bishopric of Strasbourg. It was one of only two sectarian or confessional conflicts, both highly localised, that occurred within the Holy Roman Empire between the Peace of Augsburg (1555) and the outbreak of the Thirty Years' War (1618). 

and The Thirty Years' War, a series of wars in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648. It was one of the longest and most destructive conflicts in European history, as well as the deadliest European religious war, resulting in eight million casualties.

And I could go on for a couple hundred years more

Comment: Your response appears to be intentionally facetious, however it's not particularly clever as it appears none of the scandals you cite directly intersect with the power or role of the GG. Harper's prorogation antics, on the other hand, illustrate why constitutional monarchy does nothing to protect the integrity of the Canadian political system. Harper demonstrated that a PM can effectively ignore the role that's in theory reserved for the monarch's representative. Whatever the views of those who opposed the putative coalition that was waiting in the wings at the time, in the most infamous case of Harper's machinations the GG should have insisted that the legislature be convened to decide the government's fate (which interestingly in the method by which BC's Lib government was recently dumped). Harper, though, insisted on prorogation so he could buy time to discredit the coalition and the GG was powerless to stop him, rendering the institution of monarchy utterly redundant in Canada.

Comment: in·dig·e·nous
inˈdijənəs/Submit
adjective
originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native 
 
Native Americans migrated to the New World in three waves, Harvard-led DNA analysis showsBy Carolyn Y. Johnson  July 11, 2012
An exhaustive study of DNA taken from dozens of Native American groups that span from Canada to the tip of South America is helping to settle a question that has long divided scientists: When people arrived in the Americas more than 15,000 years ago, 

The analysis published Wednesday reveals that while one population of “First Americans’’ crossed a land bridge from Siberia during the last Ice Age, giving rise to most Native Americans, there were at least two subsequent migrations. These people mixed with the founding group later, leaving traces of their genes in the DNA of present-day populations in Alaska, Greenland, and Canada.

Comment: Had great goat in Toronto last week at Ali's West Indian Roti Shop on Queen's St. I drove 30 minutes out of my way to enjoy some home cooked food and I saw people from every ethnicity and socioeconomic strata enjoying very tasty and well prepared food. The menu in many West Indian restaurants reflect the diversity and mixtures we are proud of: Indian, Chinese, Afro, Spanish and Portuguese to name a few. By definition West Indian cuisine is a melange of many tastes and cultures. "Culture vultures" may be perceived as a pariah but the flip side is maybe finally our food will be introduced to a broader audience who may not know of the superb family run restaurants like Ali's and Albert's Real Jamaican.

That may cause people to search out the "authentic" locales and in turn increase awareness and the demand from a broader audience and consumer. I will try Chubby's but for COMFORT and a feel of home there's Ali's and Albert's, something Chubby's will NEVER accomplish for an immigrant.

Comment: You're assuming the powers that profit from the huge fire fighting industry and salvage logging fiasco really want to curb wildfires. Or do they want to turn fire fear into more federal logging as timber industry lobbyists and politicians are already attempting to do?

Note that the mother of all NW forest fires, the Tillamook, was ignited by logging and fueled by logging slash. 

The 500,000 acre Biscuit fire was lightning ignited and, like this year's Chetco Bar Fire, went initially unaddressed by the USFS. One commentator notes that a timely supertanker douse might of snuffed these fires at the point of beginning. Another commentator believes that many forest fires are intentionally set for profit and plunder. And some simply blame increased fires on climate warming.

I prefer shaded fuel breaks along highways and mainlines where understories are regularly reduced but big trees and their canopies are left largely intact.

But on a hot dry windy late summer day, all bets are off.

Comment: Well, yes - and that's what insurance is. I don't buy medical services directly, I buy insurance so that should I need medical services, I can access them. But the "downside" to that is that I pay for something that I may never use. On the other hand, the upside is that because of pooled risk (and pooled money), I will be able to access medical services that I could not otherwise afford. Healthy people subsidize less healthy people, with the promise that they themselves will be subsidized when they become less healthy.

Comment: Don't compare the Y2K debacle with a Carrington Event class solar flare. A solar flare of that size could easily wipe out electronics across the country. Brushing off doomsday catastrophies doesn't mean they won't occur one day. We're overdue a sizeable asteroid impact and there's several supervolcanoes that'll one day erupt and drastically change the temperature of the world and wipe out crops and millions of people. Whilst we can only accept that we're powerless to prevent most of these disasters - don't assume for one minute that we aren't living on borrowed time on this planet.

Comment: Really?  Sustainable worlds?  There's $247 Trillion of debt in this world and only 35% of that in money supply.  How in the hell is that sustainable?  if there were a way to tax 100% of the money in the world (there isn't), it would barely cover a third of the debt.

How does the world situation correct back to rationality?  A period of Deflation in which all assets values -- stocks, bonds, and real estate -- drop about 70% in value, while cash increases 300% in value.  Of course, that probably means Depression over most of the planet.

Why did John Maynard Keynes say, "In the long run, we're all dead?"  That was in answer to the question of who deals with all this debt in the long run?  From his perspective, he was right.  He's dead and can't be held accountable for the position he's left today's young people in, responsible for paying debt they didn't incur or benefit from.

Comment: "Are we to regress to Neanderthals? By their comments and treatment of others, some already have."
===========
You did read the article, did you not? The idea that Neanderthals were. well, "Neanderthals" is changing. They were humans who may not have been as "advanced" as other human cultures but (according to the article) they were "producing tools, jewelry and impressive cave creations. They cared for their sick and elderly. They perhaps even performed a primitive kind of dentistry."
-
But while the "Neanderthal-opinion of scientists" of "Neanderthals" is slowly changing, their "Neanderthal-opinion" of "Neanderthals" as a "sub-human species" has not.....just as too many people today still think - and still consider - African Blacks/pygmies and Australian Aborigines to be "sub-human."
-
A human being is a human being regardless of where they live, how they dress, or what they do to survive in the environment in which they live.

Comment: Lets address your ignorance point by point:
1) The state employs roughly 19,000 people (4,000 are UA workers, 15,000 are state itself). Most departments have taken 10-30% cuts in the last 3 years. There isn't anywhere else to cut unless you want to feel it on the street where people live. Everyone of those citizens will have different plans that someone else will disagree with.

2) The state employee salaries (real earnings) are made public every year. The average salary last year was around $22/hr or $43,000/year for a professional. Many could make much more in the private sector, which is why state employees are hard to retain.

3) PERS has already changed. Tier IV PERS operates like a 401K, most Tier I and II folks are retired or close anyway, though you could offer early retirement to clear some of it out. Tier III is the weakest pension plan of the 3. Our unions (there's about 7) haven't negotiated deals like the MOA unions have, nor do they aim to.

Comment: To move the river water, in the winter build ice dams out of wood and water.  You build it at an angle to push the water out away from the edge upstream.  Build the ice wall out on the river about 50 feet.  You will need logs and a water pump to spay the water when it is cold.  If you have heavy equipment you can cut big blocks of ice to build an ice wall, the pump it full of water to freeze solid.  Cover it with sawdust so the ice doesn't melt.  When the river goes out in the spring, it will change the course of the river away from the bank.  If you can get some state help, get some nitrogen rods and put them down through the ice into the bottom of the river to keep the water frozen until the river changes course.

Comment: "They were chosen by researchers who pored through Denver Police data looking for the city’s persistently homeless and frequently arrested, men and women who are marked as “transient” and have rotated in and out of jail mostly for so-called “homeless” crimes — such as illegal camping, trespassing or public intoxication."

There has been some research that was done where transitioning the chronic homeless into a stable residence saves money in the end.  They are less likely to be incarcerated in the future and go through the court system and less likely to use emergency medical services.  Many find it easier to seek the mental health they need and/or the drug treatment they need and are able to transition.  Even if they do not the city/state saves money in the end.  Salt Lake City has the same type of program and has for a few years now and are finding this is the best way to care for the chronic homeless and save tax payer money in the end.

Comment: There are two separate issues here. The first is water, that precious fluid, best unpolluted, that is essential for all life. The second is Tibet, no longer, if ever, an independent sovereign state, intimately tied to a regional superpower, China. The second issue seems to be the next historical stage, post our somewhat crazy belief in an era of one superpower. Regional superpowers now abound, or are emerging, Russia, India, China, the US. They will take, in traditional colonial fashion, what they need to exploit from others - clean water, oil, precious metals, agricultural land, hydroelectric powers. We can hope for a new and later order of international law and institutions, open borders, and cultural renaissances, but only after we have lived through this time of regional superpowers, and found that that model also does not promise or provide security and well-being. The first issue is just arising, as climate change creates radically different metereological landscapes.

Comment: Hikers at least have opportunity to use good judgment: "Hmm...this area is completely encircled by head-high brush.  I can't see far in any direction.  I'd better not go in there."

Runners have less time/opportunity to do so by virtue of the rate at which they're moving, but can still sometimes change course to avoid danger.  Mountain-yuppies hurtling at speed down low-visibility trails have still less opportunity, again simply by virtue of rate-of-travel.

Which as been the point all along--moving rapidly through low-visibility terrain in bear country is dangerous--doesn't matter whether you're running, biking or sliding down on a piece of cardboard.  Moreover, the danger isn't only for you, but for others on the trail endangered by your irresponsible behavior, and of course the bears themselves.

I oppose bear-baiting.  Even by reckless morons who volunteer to be the bait--because, AGAIN, they risk others' lives besides their own.

Comment: By that logic the same could be said about the out of state oil patch workers.  They use very few services while they're based in Prudhoe.  So why should we be taxing their earnings?

Note:  That's a hypothetical.  I think we should.  Just as we should tourists.  Neither of them would be able to benefit from coming here were it not for countless 'services' they enjoy such as law enforcement, prisons, food inspections, infrastructure improvements, building inspections, wastewater plants, courts...  All of these behind-the-scenes government services combine to give them a safe and viable experience here.  

Should they pay at the same rate as residents?  No, they should pay at a proportionally higher rate because we have to maintain the services while they're away.  If they had to pay the cost of establishing those services for only the timeframes that they came here, their out of pocket costs would be enormous.

Comment: There are a number of companies (such as boat cruises) that very outwardly advertise their services as  "fireworks" events when they occur on Friday evenings.  In other words, they take advantage of the Hilton fireworks show and monetarily benefit from it.  Why not charge even a small token fee to these fireworks-related companies/events.  If I were a boat cruise marketing a Friday Fireworks special, I would be happy to pay $20 to be allowed to official advertise my business as such for my boatload of paying guests.  If companies don't want to pay a small fee, then they are not allowed to advertise.  I wonder if there is a legal way to prevent companies from profiting off of the fireworks show - at least where they market themselves that way.   There are way more than ten companies feeding off of the Hilton's show.  There's your $200!

Comment: There may or may not be a connection between the crimes in the article and the seized assets.  For the police to seize assets, they DO NOT need to have any criminal charge or conviction.  Civil Asset Forfeiture (the way police seize assets) is a civil proceeding separate and not part of the criminal proceeding.  If the police were to seize assets that are involved in a criminal conviction and those assets are controlled by an agency other than the one seizing the assets, that would be different.

Comment: "...“We can say to the alt-right and the neo-Nazis and the KKK: Get over it, you’re African, OK?”..."

Genetically she's correct, but practically she's not.  Read a really good book about two decades ago where the author tried to explain why there are cultural differences between our races.  He basically boiled it down to location.  Races that lived in the more moderate or tropical climates had many means of accessing food and the challenges by the weather for shelter was minimal.  The necessity for technology was minimized.  Cultures in climates farther away from the equator had to not only fight for resource but also develop technologies to advance in the harsher conditions.  Seemed pretty interesting.  It certainly doesn't mean someone from an equatorial climate couldn't successfully enter the more technological environment.  But, there isn't as much necessity for it.

Trump's an idiot in many ways, with or without racist behavior.

A tax on everyday essentials will do nothing to cut emissions.

Comment: @PMINZ:  The method of pedestrians holding a flag and waving it while crossing a street has been a practice in Japan for decades. The anticipated problem for this excellent safety practice could be that the flags will slowly disappear especially in Hawaii or become frail from the extended use. Comment: What is amazing about several comments is the lack of information and understanding  of a few simple facts related to crude oil quality and its processing. The quality i.e composition of crude oils vary and is a significant factor in the economics of crude purchasing and refining.The heavy oil produced in Western Canada contains about 35% material that must be processed in a residue processing unit such as a Coker or Residue Processing unit . The refining capacity in Eastern Canada is about 1.1 million barrels with only about  25000 barrels of Coking/residue processing capacity in Ontario vs about 350,000 barrels in the 1.1 million barrels from the Energy East. Significant capital expenditure will be required by the existing refiners to increase processing of Canadian bitumen derived crude so impact of Energy East pipeline on reducing crude imports will be very limited.

Comment: Oh, if only we could get the whole world to read and act on the powerful lessons the poor have to offer us. A number of years ago I had the blessing of journeying w/ the poor of Cuerna Vaca, Mexico for a mere 2 weeks. It was early Dec. and I had to take leave of my sixth grade class. The children wanted to know what I was going to teach the poor. My response was that they were going to teach me. They wondered aloud what I could learn from the poor! I promised to share my learnings w/ them upon my return. Although I learned many things during my short stay, the biggest lesson was taught me by a small group of 3 & 4 year old children who shared one small box of raisins w/ no adult promptings! Blessed are those who have the spirit of the poor.

Comment: Bob, it will NOT be the Corporations but the Tribes who have the responsibility.
Things up here in Alaska are a bit convoluted because of the status of Alaska (except Metlakatla) as a PL280 state. PL280 was passed by Congress in 1953 but was amended in 
1968.
" Many argue that because Public Law 280 was initially enacted without the consent of the Indians affected it is inherently immoral.  Although Public Law 280 was amended in 1968 requiring the consent of the tribe, consent was not required for states that had assumed jurisdiction up to 1968.  Others argue that the enactment of the law was a response to the growing fervor surrounding assimilation due to the nascent Cold War.  Still others argue it was a purely economic move on the part of the federal government.  They argue that involvement in Indian affairs was a financial burden the federal government did not want to bear. Therefore, the federal government passed the buck to the states."
States can "give" back that responsibility.

Comment: The Swedes have a name for this: döstädning. It means "death cleaning." The idea is to declutter your home before you die so your crap isn't a burden on your heirs who have to deal with it all.
Having spent 20 yrs in the military, moving about every two years or so, I learned the importance of not keeping stuff you don't really need or want. We tend to fill the available space in our living quarters.
Look around you. Think about the last time you used that old exercise equipment or that third TV. And never mind all the rubbish in your junk drawer. Why keep it all?

Comment: That's why the Church draws a distinction between objective sin and subjective culpability. The latter involves either invincible ignorance and/or psychological or physical compulsion. Accompanying people is, or should be, directed at overcoming these issues - i.e. clarifying the Commandments and guiding someone through overcoming whatever compulsion there is - not condoning their behaviour or leaving the situation as it is.

Notwithstanding this, even if a person is not in a condition of subjective guilt, Canon Law governing the distribution of the Eucharist is clear. It must be withheld from those in a situation of manifest grave sin e.g. adultery.

It is the abuse of this system that I object to.  As did Ellen White in her many public and private warnings against "kingly authority".

And indeed the system does appear to be working in this case.  The Union Conference presidents who constitute the largest plurality within the GC Executive Committee have put the GC officers on notice that the original drastic proposal will not pass.  No Union president in his right mind would vote for a proposal that would effectively permit them to be summarily dismissed by action of GC officers.

And those GC officers who proposed this are now backing down and hiding behind yet another committee.

Comment: All of the things asked for can be provided at significantly less cost, if many of the reserves affected would move to areas where there opportunities  and delivery services are feasible. There are basically zero opportunities in many remote reserves, which means that to pursue higher education the young must move away. This hardly what reserves want as the young insure the survival of the reserve. The hard truth is the government is finding it difficult as it always has, to find people willing to go and work on isolated reserves, this factor alone will always make delivery of services a challenge. Water treatment plants have been built on remote reserves, but these require expertise and constant maintenance, something that is in short supply on isolated reserves. If you  look at reserves located close to urban areas and then look at reserves that are isolated and then examine what the difficulties are, the inescapable conclusion is that isolated reserves must move.

Comment: It has been over a decade since the "No Child Left Behind" of W went into effect at the national level. NO improvements have occurred because kids aren't widgets to be measured, tested, improved. Many observers already have attacked the poor quality of the test itself, the hours of classroom instruction it usurps, and the wrong-headed deductions made from it.
Our schools need smaller class sizes, a return to the days of many extracurriculars (kids learn much, character-wise, from them), and a lessening of the test pressures  (ACT; SAT) that already overwhelm students. 
That said, Obama and Sec. of Ed. Duncan have led efforts to make it easier to release bad teachers that, presently, notoriously are difficult or impossible to fire. 
To continue to obsess over school testing while at the same time continuing to seriously underfund schools is counter-productive.
Not so long ago, Eugene and Corvallis had nation-leading schools--- but this was before Measure 5 and No Child Left Behind.

Comment: The calculator asks for an average expected rate of return, NOT an interest rate.  Interest rates for things like GICs and aaa bonds will likely track inflation anyways. I would imagine most TFSA do not have much interest-bearing securities in them, unless the investor finds that avoiding tax on GICs makes sense for him, as they are taxed at a higher rate than capital gains on growth securities like stocks/funds, and they keep those in other holdings like RRSP or non-registered accounts.

Comment: I lived at the Mission during the early 80's and am still in awe of its work and those who do the work. I am not a Christian, but view the Mission as a great example of what quiet devotion to one's principles can do. And there were many stories of men who not only got food and shelter, but companionship that gave them the will to keep on keeping on. 
Sure, I wish the Mission would find a way to cooperate with Lane County to act as the official emergency shelter, seeing as how Lane County has none, but the Christian community that supports the Mission can be proud of what their dollars are doing. Some of the finest men I ever met lived at the Mission, slept in its beds and worked on the trucks gathering newspaper for recycling. Some struggled with major demons, but with the help of the Mission they were able to keep breathing and have a sense of dignity. 
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: What I remember most about these floods, is the incredible stupidity on the part of sightseers.

I saw people duck under the "Police Line - Do Not Cross" tape we had strung along Bear Creek in Jeffco, to go down and get a better look at the water.  I even caught one idiot with his two-year old child toddling around the bank next to the rushing water.

Dumb, sullen looks in response.  Apparently I was the bad guy.
